title: 108_hr1684
content: The "Student Adjustment Act of 2003" repeals a section of the Illegal Immigration Reform and Immigrant Responsibility Act of 1996, restoring the state's option to determine residency for higher education benefits. It also addresses the adjustment of status for certain long-term resident students. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to include a special rule for children in middle or secondary school, allowing for cancellation of removal and adjustment to lawful permanent resident status. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to include a special rule for children in middle or secondary school, allowing for cancellation of removal and adjustment to lawful permanent resident status for aliens meeting specific criteria. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to include a special rule for children in middle or secondary school, allowing for cancellation of removal and adjustment to lawful permanent resident status for eligible individuals enrolled in school or pursuing higher education in the United States. The Secretary of Homeland Security will establish a procedure for affirmative application for relief without removal proceedings. The provisions of this paragraph restrict the application to certain aliens who are inadmissible or deportable under specific sections of the Immigration and Nationality Act, unless extreme hardship would result from their removal. The paragraph discusses restrictions on the application for certain aliens who are inadmissible or deportable under specific sections of the Immigration and Nationality Act. It also includes exemptions from numerical limitations and grandfather provisions for certain individuals applying under the mentioned sections. Individuals under the age of 21 on specific dates and meeting certain requirements are eligible under this section. The section outlines the confidentiality of information provided by applicants, restricting its use to application determinations only and prohibiting identification of individuals or access by unauthorized personnel. Whoever violates this by using, publishing, or allowing information to be examined may face a fine of up to $10,000. Additionally, eligibility for Federal Educational Assistance is extended to aliens granted relief under specific sections of the Immigration and Nationality Act. Regulations are also addressed in the section. The Secretary of Homeland Security must publish proposed regulations within 60 days and final regulations within 120 days of the enactment of the Act. The final regulations will be effective immediately on an interim basis but may be revised after a public comment period.
